title: About Me
text: On this page you will find my answers to some questions that I am commonly asked. If there are any other questions that you think I should add to this page, please email me and let me know!

title: About Me
section: What do you do for a living?
text:
What do you do for a living?
I am a third-year doctoral student in Biostatistics and Data Science at the University of Mississippi Medical Center. I am employed as a graduate assistant in the Department of Preventive Medicine through a grant funded by the Mississippi Department of Education for my work with the Mississippi School-based Telehealth Program. Additionally, I am employed as an independent statistical consultant for the Mississippi Public Health Institute.

title: About Me
section: A lot of your research is focused on adolescents; is there a reason for that?
text:
A lot of your research is focused on adolescents; is there a reason for that?
Yes, I intentionally decided to dedicate my research efforts to adolescents and children, more broadly. I believe, for several reasons, that children are understudied relative to their adult counterparts and that this should not be the case. I also believe that as a researcher I should try to make the world a better place for future generations. In my eyes, there is no better way to do that than by trying to keep children happy and healthy. Through my research I try to identify the specific challenges facing children, so that others may better be able to remedy them.

title: About Me
section: A lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; are you from there?
text:
A lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; are you from there?
No, I am not from Mississippi. I have only lived in Mississippi for the last couple of years while attending graduate school, but I have thoroughly enjoyed my time here. I am originally from Schwenksville, PA, which is a small suburb of Philadelphia. I lived there until I moved to Memphis, TN to attend Rhodes College.
While I am not originally from Mississippi, it is the focus of much of my research because there are many strong, clear health challenges that face the state, and I want to do the best that I can to help address them.

title: About Me
text:
What are your research interests?
My research interests are quite varied, as you could probably gather. I am broadly interested in research in longitudinal studies/methods, survey methodology, missing data methods, cardiometabolic health, psychology, pediatrics, and the intersections of each of these topics.

title: About Me
text:
What are your career goals?
Upon graduating from my PhD program, if fate so decrees, I intend to do a postdoctoral fellowship. This is because I would like to gain more experience and further develop my academic interests prior to applying for faculty positions. I, ultimately, would like to be a professor because I thoroughly enjoy teaching and passing on my love for statistics and science to others. If you have any advice for me on how to best accomplish either of these goals, please reach out!

title: About Me
text:
Are you open to opportunities?
I am always open to new experiences. Thus, if you are interested in collaborating with me, having me deliver a presentation/seminar, or hiring me, please feel free to reach out!

title: Suicidal Ideation and Behavior in Adolescents
text: The problem of suicide in the United States represents a deeply concerning and complex public health issue. Over the past few decades, the nation has witnessed a distressing upward trend in suicide rates across various age groups, with particularly alarming increases among adolescents and young adults. According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), suicide ranks as the 10th leading cause of death in the country. Each year, tens of thousands of individuals succumb to suicide, leaving behind devastated families, friends, and communities. The impact of suicide extends far beyond the loss of life, as it generates profound emotional and psychological distress among those affected and imposes significant economic costs on society. Understanding the underlying factors, such as mental health challenges, societal pressures, access to lethal means, and insufficient mental health resources, is crucial in developing comprehensive strategies to prevent suicide and promote mental well-being nationwide.

title: Suicidal Ideation and Behavior in Adolescents

title: Compliance in Intensive Longitudinal Studies
text: Intensive longitudinal methods refer to research approaches that involve gathering repeated, high-frequency measurements over a short period of time to capture the dynamic nature of individual behavior, experiences, and processes. These methods aim to provide a detailed and nuanced understanding of how individuals change and evolve within their natural environments. By collecting data at frequent intervals, such as multiple times a day or week, intensive longitudinal methods allow researchers to examine within-person variability, patterns, and fluctuations in real-time. These approaches often employ various data collection techniques, including electronic diaries, ecological momentary assessments (EMAs), wearable sensors, or smartphone applications. The rich and fine-grained data obtained through intensive longitudinal methods can shed light on the intricacies of human behavior, emotions, and interactions, offering valuable insights into individual differences, developmental processes, and the impact of contextual factors.

title: Compliance in Intensive Longitudinal Studies
text:
YRBS

title: Pediatric Obesity and Metabolic Syndrome
text:
Obesity and metabolic syndrome are two interrelated health problems that pose significant challenges to individuals and society as a whole. Obesity, characterized by excessive body fat accumulation, has reached epidemic proportions globally, including in the United States. It is a complex condition influenced by a combination of genetic, environmental, and behavioral factors. The consequences of obesity extend far beyond physical appearance, as it significantly increases the risk of developing various chronic diseases, such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, certain types of cancer, and musculoskeletal disorders.
Metabolic syndrome, on the other hand, refers to a cluster of metabolic abnormalities that often coexist and heighten the risk of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. These abnormalities include central obesity (excess fat around the waist), elevated blood pressure, impaired glucose regulation, dyslipidemia (abnormal levels of cholesterol and triglycerides), and pro-inflammatory and pro-thrombotic states. The prevalence of metabolic syndrome has risen in parallel with the obesity epidemic, making it a significant public health concern.
Both obesity and metabolic syndrome are intricately linked, with obesity being a primary risk factor for the development of metabolic syndrome. This vicious cycle perpetuates negative health outcomes, as metabolic abnormalities further contribute to weight gain and worsen existing obesity-related health complications. Moreover, these conditions have substantial economic implications, as the costs associated with medical treatments, lost productivity, and reduced quality of life place a considerable burden on individuals, families, and healthcare systems.
Addressing the problems of obesity and metabolic syndrome requires a comprehensive approach encompassing individual lifestyle modifications, public health initiatives, and healthcare interventions. Strategies should focus on promoting healthy eating habits, regular physical activity, and weight management, while also addressing societal and environmental factors that contribute to the obesogenic environment. Additionally, early detection, risk assessment, and timely intervention are crucial in managing metabolic syndrome and preventing its associated complications. By raising awareness, implementing evidence-based interventions, and fostering a supportive environment, it is possible to mitigate the impact of obesity and metabolic syndrome and improve the overall health and well-being of individuals and communities.

title: Programming in Julia: Getting Started
text:
Download Julia
I hope that it comes as no surprise that to program in Julia we must first have it downloaded onto our computer. To do this, click here on “Julia”, find your operating system (Windows, MacOS, etc.) in the table shown below, and download the corresponding installation file.





Then, access the file you have just downloaded and proceed with the prompted installation process.
And…poof! Julia is now installed on your computer. But, now what?
We need to install an integrated development environment (IDE) to more easily program in Julia. Our weapon of choice will be Visual Studio Code aka VS Code.

title: Programming in Julia: Getting Started
text:
Install VSCode
Click here on “VSCode”, find your operating system (Windows, MacOS, etc.) among the options listed below, and download the corresponding installation file.





Then, access the file you have just downloaded and proceed with the prompted installation process.
Now you have both VSCode and Julia installed on your computer! However, we are not quite ready to start programming in Julia. There are a couple more things that we need to do.

title: Programming in Julia: Getting Started
text:
Install Extensions
Go ahead and start/open VS Code. To access Extensions you have two options. First, you can select the View tab and then choose Extensions or second, you can select the Extensions icon on the lefthand side of VSCode (shown below). In Extensions, type in and select “julia” (no quotation marks), and then click the Install button.





We now have Julia setup and ready to go in VSCode!
Before we continue, we are going to install another extension. This step is optional, but highly recommended. Go back to Extensions and type in, select, and install “quarto” (no quotation marks).
Our structural framework is now complete and we can actually begin our Julia programming journey!

import Pkg
let
    pkgs = ["XLSX", "DataFrames", "Plots", "StatsBase", "IJulia", "GLM"]
    for pkg in pkgs
        if Base.find_package(pkg) === nothing
            Pkg.add(pkg)
        end
    end
end

title: Programming in Julia: Getting Started
text:
Import and Clean the Data

using DataFrames, CSV, XLSX

Data = DataFrame(CSV.File("/Users/brianchristman/Desktop/Projects/POMS/POMS_Clean.csv"))
Data1 = DataFrame(XLSX.readtable("/Users/brianchristman/Desktop/Projects/POMS/POMS.xlsx", "Latest Data with Specialty"))
